note1.text:
[color=524839][u] Principles of Evidence Collection[/u][/color] 
[color=524839][b]Admissibility:[/b][/color] Evidence must be obtained legally. 
[color=524839][b]Integrity:[/b][/color] Evidence must remain unaltered. 
[color=524839][b]Chain of Custody:[/b][/color] Evidence handling must be documented. 
[color=524839][b]Repeatability:[/b][/color] The procedures carried out must be able to be reproduced 
[color=524839][b]Proportionality:[/b][/color] Investigations must respect rights. 

[color=524839][u]Evidence Collection Process[/u][/color]
[color=524839][b]Identification:[/b][/color] Identify digital evidence sources. 
[color=524839][b]Preservation:[/b][/color] Do not alter or delete any evidence, ensure write blockers are used. Create bit-by-bit copies of evidence. 
[color=524839][b]Collection:[/b][/color] Seizure devices correctly, ensuring volatile data is collected before shutting down. 
[color=524839][b]Documentation:[/b][/color] Ensure contemporaneous notes and chain of custody is maintained. Log every action. 
[color=524839][b]Analysis:[/b][/color] Recover deleted files, analyse data.

[color=524839][u]Chain of Custody[/u][/color] 
Documentation of who, what, when, and where the evidence has been.

note2.text:
[color=524839][u]Creating Forensic Image Files[/u][/color] 
A bit-for-bit copy of digital media. 

[color=524839][b]Free Tools:[/b][/color] FTK Imager, Guymager, Autopsy. 

[color=524839][u]Procedure[/u][/color] 
[color=524839]1.[/color] Ensure the use of a write blocker for physical devices.
[color=524839]2.[/color] Create disk image.
[color=524839]3.[/color] Select source. 
[color=524839]4.[/color] Select image type: dd, e01. 
[color=524839]5.[/color] Case information. 
[color=524839]6.[/color] Hash verification: MD5, SHA1, SHA256, SHA512. 

[color=524839][u]ACPO Principles[/u][/color]
[color=524839]1.[/color] No action taken should change the data held on a digital device that may be used as evidence in court. 
[color=524839]2.[/color] If access is necessary the person accessing must be competent to do so and be able to explain their actions in court. 
[color=524839]3.[/color] An audit trail or recor of all actions taken that have been applied to the digital evidence should be created and preserved. Ensuring a third party expert can follow those processes and reach the same conclusion. 
 [color=524839]4.[/color] The investigator in charge has overall responsibility to ensure the principles are followed.

note3.text:
[color=524839][u]Hex Viewing[/u][/color]

The inspection of digital data in hexadecimal format. 

[color=524839][b]Free Tools:[/b][/color] WinHex, HxD, FTK Imager, Autopsy. 

[color=524839][u]Key Features[/u][/color]
[color=524839]Offset:[/color] Memory address/location. 
[color=524839]Hex Data:[/color] Raw hex values. 
[color=524839]ASCII View:[/color] Human-readable text. 

[color=524839][u]Common File Signatures[/u][/color]
[color=524839]JPG:[/color] FF D8 FF 
[color=524839]PDF:[/color] 25 50 44   46 
[color=524839]EXE:[/color] 4D 5A 
[color=524839]PNG:[/color] 89 50 4E 47

note4.text:
[color=524839][u]Hex Analysis[/u][/color] 

[color=524839][u]Basics[/u][/color]
[color=524839]Hexadecimal:[/color] Base-16. Digits 0-9 followed by letters A-F. e.g. 28 = 1C 
[color=524839]Byte:[/color] 2 hex digits e.g. FF/ 
[color=524839]Offset:[/color] The address of a byte e.g. 0x00000001.

[color=524839][u]File Carving[/u][/color]
[color=524839]1.[/color] Identify file headers and footers. 
[color=524839]2.[/color] Select all data between the start and end signatures. 
[color=524839]3.[/color] Save with the correlating file extension. 

[color=524839][u]Use Cases[/u][/color] 
Recover deleted files.
Extract hidden data. 
Identify known hex patterns to identify malware or obfuscation.

note5.text:
[color=524839][u]Metadata[/u][/color]
Data about data.

[color=524839][u]Metadata Sources:[/u][/color]
MS Office Docs - Author, Modification and Creation dates.
JPEG images - EXIF data.
PDFs - Creator, Modification and Creation dates.
Emails - Sender, Recipient, Date and Time. 

[color=524839][u]Use Cases[/u][/color]
Track file movement between systems.
Recover deleted file information. 
Link an individual to a device or location via GPS information.
Establish a timeline of events.
Detect file tampering.
[color=524839][u]Limitations[/u][/color]
Metadata can be easily manipulated, especially EXIF data. 
Platforms typically remove metadata from uploaded images or files.
Compression of files can partially or fully destroy any metadata.

[color=524839][b]Free Tools:[/b][/color] ExifRead, ExifTool, FTK Imager, Autopsy.

note6.text:
[color=524839]EXIF Data:[/color] Exchangeable Image File Format. 
A type of metadata found embedded within image files, such as JPEG and TIFF file formats.
Created automatically by digital cameras and smartphones.
Stored with the image file bytes.

[color=524839][u]Common Tags[/u][/color]
[color=524839]GPSLongitude/GPSLatitude:[/color] The GPS coordinates of the location the image was taken. 
[color=524839]DateTimeOriginal:[/color] When the photo was initially taken.[color=524839]DateTimeDigitized:[/color] When the image was digitized.
[color=524839]Make and Model:[/color] of the imaging device.
[color=524839]Software:[/color] Identification of post-processing software.

[color=524839][u]Use Cases[/u][/color]
[color=524839]Device Attribution: [/color] Through the analysis of an imaging devices serial number.
[color=524839]Tampering Observation: [/color] Identification of metadata tampering, or software tags revealing post-processing. 
[color=524839]Timeline Reconstruction:[/color] Through the use of DateTimeOriginal and GPSDate/TimeStamp the time of capture can be verified.
[color=524839]Geolocation Evidence:[/color] The observation of GPS tags can place a person at a crime scene.
